instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance – this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.PP1V5_S3RS0: What is PP1V5_S3RS0? PP1V5_S3RS0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message:
Hi Team,
I have a 820-3208which had a liquid damage.
At the begining it had no sign of life then i replaced <CAPACITOR>C5025</CAPACITOR> and passed it the Ultrasonic cleaner now the fan turns ON it, that turns ON (Fan spins) but doesn,t start:

after i've checked all the votages again i've noticed that <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> is at 0V:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> : 8,38
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> :3,417

5V Rails:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> : 5,126
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> : 5,126
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> :5,128
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> : 5,122

3.3V Rails:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> :3,331
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> :3,330
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> :3,331
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> :3,325
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> :3,325

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 1,786

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL>: 1,355 MAYBE LOW?

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL>: 1,355 MAYBE LOW?

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>: 1,510

<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL>: 0,678
<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>: 0,674
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>: 0,856
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>: 1,042
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>: 1,072

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>: 1,118
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL>: 1,355
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCPQE</SIGNAL>: 1,052
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_CPU_VCCPLL_R</SIGNAL>: 1,787

Then I removed <RESISTOR>R7550</RESISTOR>, to notice that i have 2,8 Ohms between the ground and <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_VCCAXG</SIGNAL> line ( Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7550</RESISTOR>), i have 0,833V at the pin 2 of L7550 without <RESISTOR>R7550</RESISTOR> insteac of 1,05V.
i've also notice that <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> is getting warm.
What should be the best way to troubleshoot that? should i remove all the capacitors on the on the CPU Decoupling page?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message: Put back <RESISTOR>R7550</RESISTOR>, do a PRAM reset, <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_VCCAXG</SIGNAL> will only come up with a display connected..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message:
Hi Aprendiz, thanks for your reply,
i've tried a PRAM reset without sucess, so i took a look at <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>, this one doesn't receive the EN signal on pin 1 from <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> SMC, 3,3V is pesent on pin 2 and 3 and <RESISTOR>R9014</RESISTOR> is 99m8Ohms (1KOhm)
Has i precised it in the tillte, the SMC <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> is getting war, that why i really suspect <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>.
Could you please confirm

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message: <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> is not the SMC, is the PCH, and of course will get a little warm, what is the voltage on L7510?? Do you have the display connected???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message: Your PPBUS Voltage is low at 8.38 volts. I suspect crap under the SMC or dead SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message:
Sorry I don't know why i wrote smc , because i'm talking about <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> ( PCH ) sorry.
Yes The screen is connected, regarding the voltage on L7510 i've mesured 1,125V instead of 1,25V.

What i did is that i've bypassed <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> pin 2-3 and 4-5 to bring the 3,3V on L9004. But still <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_VCCAXG</SIGNAL> stays to 0V.
I would supspect more the PCH <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> than the SMC no?
If yes do you know the right reference of the PCH (<CHIP>U1800</CHIP>) , because i couldn't find the PCH on ebay with the ref in the pdf : " INTEL PANTHER POINT - MPCH <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> 1017P " or " QP8D-MM915462 "

thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message:
Don't bypass things like that, that is a good way to completely fry the board. 
Connect one of the speakers and check if there is a beep.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message:
Hi Dukefawks, ok i'll remove the jumper i did.
The speakers are both connected and no chime and/or beep.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message: This could be anything. Corrosion under SMC? Where was the original corrosion?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message: Almost everywhere, it was a dark liquid like coca cola....because it was like caramel inside.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message: Corrosion under some chip. Could be SMC, could be PCH, could be RAM. You saw the original damage and you need to make an assessment as to which chips may have crud under them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message:
OK, so i think i'll re pass it in the UC if not OK, remove one by one smc, pch. 
Which one should i remove first ? Smc or pch ? I would say pch as this one is getting hot. 
But maybe before doing all that  i'll try to get another screen to test it. 
Can i try with a mbp 13 dispkay ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message:
Hi Dukfawks, 
I've tried to plug 2 different display (mba 11, 2010 and mbp 13 retina 2012) and it's still the same no sound, no backlight, not booting so now the next step would be to inspect the smc, pch. 
Which one first you'd recomand me ? Smc ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message: Define "hot"? Can you keep your finger on it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message:
It's not burning if you keep your finger on it. 
Just removed the smc and tried to put it back without reballing,(don't have the stencil), so now the fan spins then stops alternatively. I'll order a New reballed one and install it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> TURNS ON BUT NOT STARTING,  <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> 0V,  <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> Warm
threads.message: You cannot order a reballed SMC. They have firmware and cannot be exchanged between different board models. Get an identical donor board and reball that SMC.
